channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Is the Coronavirus in Your Backyard?
item.description: White-tailed deer could become a reservoir for the virus, putting people and animals at risk, health experts say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suresh Kuchipudi, a veterinary microbiologist at Penn State University in State College, Pa., with Cashew, a young white-tailed deer in the university’s deer research center.

item.title: Climate Change Enters the Therapy Room
item.description: Ten years ago, psychologists proposed that a wide range of people would suffer anxiety and grief over climate. Skepticism about that idea is gone.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times

item.title: The Pandemic Has Made Many Seniors Less Active
item.description: Health experts are concerned that the pandemic, in upending daily routines, has reduced mobility and physical conditioning in older adults.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Bryan Meltz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cindy Myers of Petaluma, Calif., an executive in the Bay Area, has been working from home for two years, and the change has taken a physical and mental toll, she said.

item.title: Pandemic Era Tests May Speed Hepatitis-C Detection
item.description: A wave of diagnostics ushered in by Covid could help revive flagging efforts to eliminate the disease.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Lucinda Grande, outside the Pioneer Family Practice in Lacey, Wash.

item.title: Younger Americans Benefited Less From Booster Shots Than Older People
item.description: Among those under age 50, vaccination even without a booster protected strongly against hospitalization and death, according to new C.D.C. data.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a booster in the Bronx last month. The data suggest that boosters are most essential for older adults and those who have certain immune conditions or live in long-term care facilities.

item.title: Consistently wearing high-quality masks offers strong protection, a study in California suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shopping for pomelos in Chinatown in Oakland, Calif., in January.

item.title: In New York City Sewage, a Mysterious Coronavirus Signal
item.description: For the past year, scientists have been looking for the source of strange coronavirus sequences that have appeared in the city’s wastewater.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica Trujillo, a microbiologist at Queensborough Community College, filtered bacteria from a wastewater sample containing traces of coronavirus.

item.title: Why Nasal Covid Vaccines May Make Better Boosters
item.description: Nasal vaccines under development around the world may make better boosters by stopping the coronavirus in the airways.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Amarjeet Kumar Singh/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Waiting after a booster shot of the Covaxin vaccine, manufactured by Bharat Biotech, in New Delhi last month. The company now has approval to begin Phase 3 trials of its nasal vaccine.

item.title: A Cancer Treatment Makes Leukemia Vanish, but Creates More Mysteries
item.description: Two early recipients of CAR T immunotherapy were free of a blood cancer nearly a decade after receiving the therapy.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Keith R. Porter/Science Source
item.media:description: A colorized scanning electron micrograph of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a type of leukemia that affects B cells and accounts for a quarter of new leukemia cases each year.

item.title: Chimps Catch Insects to Put on Wounds. Is It Folk Medicine?
item.description: They don’t eat the bugs, and they’re definitely applying them to wounds, so some scientists think the primates may be treating one another’s injuries.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bakalar

item.title: Looking for Early Warning Signs of Pancreatic Cancer
item.description: Scientists are exploring whether the onset of diabetes may in some cases herald the existence of one of the most deadly of all cancers.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody
item.media:credit: Lilli Carré

item.title: Omicron Helped Clarify Pfizer Vaccine Efficacy in Young Kids, Gottlieb Says
item.description: At the urging of the federal government, Pfizer and its partner BioNTech applied last week for authorization for two doses of its Covid vaccine to children ages 4 and younger.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Emily Matthews/Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 5-year-old girl receiving her first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in Pittsburgh last month.

item.title: Afghanistan’s Health Care System Is Collapsing Under Stress
item.description: Hospitals and clinics are struggling to hold up amid a cash shortage and a vast surge of malnutrition and disease. By one estimate, 90 percent may close in the next few months.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino, Safiullah Padshah and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:description: A nurse tends to a child at an Intensive Care Unit for severe cases at the Indira Gandhi Children’s Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, this month.

item.title: Covid-19 Commission Modeled on 9/11 Inquiry Draws Bipartisan Backing
item.description: A broad, bipartisan group of senators is coalescing around a plan for an independent panel to investigate the origins of the coronavirus and the U.S. response.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: National Commission on Terrorist Attacks upon the United States
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senators Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, and Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, have proposed legislation to create a Covid-19 commission.

item.title: Lawmakers Press Amazon on Sales of Chemical Used in Suicides
item.description: Even as grieving families tried to warn Amazon and other e-commerce sites of the danger, there were more purchases and more deaths.
item.dc:creator: Megan Twohey and Gabriel J.X. Dance
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruth Scott, whose son killed himself using a food preservative he bought on Amazon, has filed a wrongful-death suit.

item.title: Medicare Will Soon Provide Free At-Home Coronavirus Tests
item.description: The announcement came after lawmakers and advocates argued that Medicare recipients had been passed over in the push to require insurers to cover the tests.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The free tests covered by Medicare would go to some of the most vulnerable parts of the U.S. population.

item.title: Body Odor May Smell Worse to You Than Your Ancient Ancestors
item.description: Researchers worked out which receptors in your nose detect particular scent molecules, and found evidence of evolutionary change in some of these genes.
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones
item.media:credit: Andia/Alamy
item.media:description: Humans have around 800 olfactory receptor genes, but only about half of those are functional — that is, translated into proteins that hang out in the nose and detect odor molecules.

item.title: F.D.A. Nominee Faces Steep Climb to Senate Confirmation
item.description: Dr. Robert Califf, a former agency commissioner, is encountering opposition over federal opioid and abortion policies and his industry ties.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Emily Cochrane
item.category: Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Robert Califf, President Biden’s nominee to lead the F.D.A., testified before the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions in December.

item.title: Was He Really Having a Heart Attack?
item.description: The doctor insisted he was — but he felt it couldn’t be true. One of them was right.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Sanders, M.D.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Ina Jang

item.title: Vuity Review: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
item.description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vuity, eyedrops that can help people see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market in December.

item.title: Biden to Present Plan to Cut Cancer Death Rate in Half
item.description: The president aims to revive the cancer “moonshot” program, but experts expressed doubt that it would be possible to reduce the death rate so profoundly.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden called on the National Cancer Institute to coordinate with cancer treatment centers to offer screenings around the country.

item.title: What the 'Active Grandparent Hypothesis' Tells Us About Aging Well
item.description: The need for healthy, active grandparents who can help with child-rearing may be encoded in our genes.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Promised 500 Million Free Covid Tests. Then He Had to Find Them.
item.description: Millions of Americans are now receiving tests through the new mail program, which health experts said came too late to meet demand during the brunt of Omicron wave.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: After previously focusing on making medical devices like forehead thermometers, iHealth is now a major supplier of at-home tests to the federal government.

item.title: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Clear 2 Vaccine Doses for Young Children as a Start
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration asked to review Pfizer’s data on two doses now, while the company continues to assess whether three doses would be more effective.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paxton Bowers, 5, a leukemia patient at Texas Children’s Hospital in Houston, received a coronavirus shot in November. Shots for children younger than 5 could be authorized this month.

item.title: Alan A. Stone, 92, Dies; Challenged Psychiatry’s Use in Public Policy
item.description: An iconoclastic thinker, he greatly influenced the evolution of psychiatric ethics, and guided the decision to take homosexuality off the list of mental disorders.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: The New Normal, a Virtual Event on Life and Love After Omicron
item.description: David Leonhardt of The Morning newsletter hosts a live conversation to explain this moment in the pandemic and to hear your Tiny Love Stories.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Tribes Reach $590 Million Opioid Settlement With Johnson & Johnson
item.description: Money from the tentative deal would go toward addiction and treatment and would be overseen by Native American tribal leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Eric Baradat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: If most tribes sign on, as expected, the settlement will be noted for its size as well as its acknowledgement of the 574 federally recognized tribes as a distinct litigating entity.

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Pfizer to Ask FDA to Authorize Covid-19 Vaccine for Children Under 5
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mila Pagador, 5, speaking to registered nurse Ashley Bean before she received her dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in Albuquerque, N.M., last year.

item.title: Maker of Hubble Contact Lenses to Pay $3.5 Million in FTC Settlement
item.description: Industry professionals told The Times in 2019 that Hubble switched people out of their prescribed lens brands and into Hubble’s lenses, which could be harmful to customers.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:credit: Jessica Emily Marx for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hubble marketed itself heavily through social media and sought to mimic the success of other direct-to-consumer companies like Harry’s and Dollar Shave Club.
